simplified: Your dreams might show you thoughts you didn’t know you had. Dreams like flying, falling, losing your teeth, or being in public without clothes often mean something similar for many people. But to understand what they mean for you, think about what’s happening in your life and how you feel.
original: Your dreams might show you all kinds of insights into things that you didn't realise you were thinking about. Common dreams like being able to fly or falling, your teeth falling out or having no clothes on in a public place probably mean something similar in most people. But the key to understanding exactly what they mean to you is to connect them to the events and feelings in your daily life.

simplified: One of the most interesting examples of wild animals living in a city is the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, about 35,000 wild dogs live on the streets. Some of these dogs were born in the wild, and others are pets that their owners left behind. Some dogs live alone, while others live in groups called packs. In 2010, scientists studied these dogs and found that they have adapted very well to city life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street when people are crossing, and some dogs even seem to understand traffic lights.
original: One of the most interesting cases of wild animals living in a city are the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, there are approximately 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some of the dogs were born wild, while others are pets that have been abandoned by their owners. Some dogs live alone and others live in packs. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and found that the dogs have adapted remarkably successfully to urban life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people and some dogs appear to understand traffic lights.

simplified: Wonder is the first book by RJ Palacio, who lives in New York. On her website, she says she got the idea after seeing a girl with a face that looked different one day. The book has sold very well in the United States and has won many awards. Schools often use it to talk about bullying, friendship, and how it feels to be different. A movie based on the book is being made. Many people, including me, are excited to see what RJ Palacio writes next.
original: Wonder is New Yorker RJ Palacio's first novel. On her website, she explains that the idea for the book came to her after seeing a girl with facial deformities on the street one day. Wonder has been a bestseller in the United States and has already won several awards. Many schools are using it as a starting point for discussions about bullying, friendship and what it's like to be different. A film version is being made, and many, including me, are waiting eagerly to see what RJ Palacio writes next.

simplified: Chloe has two pet rats named Zena and Roxy. She knows rats are not common pets, and she’s lost count of how many times she’s had to explain to people that rats aren’t dirty. She tells them that rats can be great pets if you take good care of them. But she also understands why some people don’t like rats — she didn’t like them either, at first. Then her friend Martin showed her his pet rats. She saw how smart and loving they were, and that changed her mind. Last year, when one of Martin’s rats had babies, Chloe decided she wanted two of them for herself.
original: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they're not typical pets and she has lost count of the times she's patiently tried to explain to people that rats aren't dirty and they make fantastic pets if you look after them correctly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how affectionate and intelligent they were. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she'd like to have two of them.

simplified: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some have been hurt or killed by cars, and others have died after touching electric wires while playing. Baboons are at risk of disappearing, so the city has hired Baboon Monitors to help protect them. These monitors try to keep baboons out of towns by chasing them away or catching them and taking them back to the wild. This has helped a bit, but it’s hard to stop baboons from returning to the city when they know they can find easy food there.
original: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some have been injured or killed in car accidents and others have been electrocuted as they played with electric cables. Baboons are an endangered species and to save them and minimise conflicts between humans and baboons, the city council has employed a team of Baboon Monitors. The monitors' job is to chase baboons out of urban areas or catch them and release them in the countryside. This policy has had some success, though it is proving hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city once they see it as a source of easy food.

simplified: I work for a big international IT company. Their main office is in the United States, so I do all my work from home using the internet. This means I don’t have to travel to work or spend time talking casually with coworkers. I work on one project at a time, and I like this because it gives me freedom. If my kids have a school event or I need to see the dentist, I can take time off easily. The bad side is that since I don’t have fixed working hours, I often keep working late into the night. Sometimes I even miss dinner to finish a job.
original: I work for a global IT company, but because their headquarters is in the States, I do all my work online from home. That means that I don't waste time commuting or making idle chit-chat with colleagues. I work on a project basis, and this flexibility is very valuable to me because it means that I can easily take some time off when my children need me to go to their school performances or if I need to schedule an appointment with the dentist. The downside is that without clear office hours, I tend to work well into the evening, sometimes skipping dinner to finish a task.

simplified: In the 1990s, graffiti kept going, but street art also grew fast around the world. Some artists wanted to share political messages and made art to make people think about war, unfair treatment, and inequality. Others wanted to create beautiful and eye-catching pieces. In South America, many street artists painted in poor neighborhoods, bringing color, energy, and beauty to dull city walls.
original: In the 1990s, graffiti continued but there was also an explosion in street art around the world. Some artists wanted to make political points and produced art that tried to make people think about war, inequality and discrimination. Other street artists were more concerned with producing beautiful, attractive work. In South America, many street artists went to work in poor areas adding colour, life and beauty to grey, city walls.

simplified: Social media, magazines, and shop windows show people new things to buy every day. In the UK, people are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Shopping online makes it easy to buy things without thinking. Big brands sell clothes so cheaply that people treat them like things you use once and throw away – wearing them just two or three times before getting rid of them.
original: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people daily with things to buy, and British consumers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping means it is easy for customers to buy without thinking, while major brands offer such cheap clothes that they can be treated like disposable items – worn two or three times and then thrown away.

simplified: Sam squinted at the dust cloud from the car driving up to the Big House. The horses swished their tails at flies, not bothered by their owner’s first visit in ten months. Sam waited. Mr. Carter didn’t come out here unless he had to—and that suited Sam just fine. The less he saw of his boss, the safer his job. Mr. Carter wiped sweat from his neck. Dark patches on his shirt spread together like countries on a map. His skin was already red from the June sun. Otherwise, he had the pale look of someone who stayed indoors while others worked.
original: Sam squinted against the sun at the distant dust trail raked up by the car on its way up to the Big House. The horses kicked and flicked their tails at flies, not caring about their owner's first visit in ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't come out here unless he had to, which was just fine by Sam. The more he kept out of his boss's way, the longer he'd have a job. Mr, Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. The damp patches on his shirt drew together like shapes in an atlas. His skin was already turning ruddy in the June sun. Otherwise he had the indoor tan of a man that made money while other people did the work.

simplified: Many people in Berlin, Germany said killing wild pigs was too cruel. This caused strong arguments between hunters and people who care about animals. Because of the complaints, the city decided to try a calmer way to deal with the pigs. Instead of shooting them, they built fences and made it against the law to feed the pigs. It’s not yet clear if this will work. But it could be hard to stop the pigs from spreading, especially because warmer winters help them grow in number.
original: Many city residents in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was unnecessarily cruel and there were heated arguments between hunters and animal lovers. In response to protests, the city council decided to take more peaceful action against pigs. Instead of shooting them, they have put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. Time will tell if this strategy works, though it may be a losing battle as warmer winters mean that pig numbers are greater than in the past.

simplified: One big idea for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne Collins’s love of old Greek stories. When she was young, her favorite story was Theseus and the Minotaur. In this tale, the city of Athens is ruled by Crete, but the people of Athens fight back. As punishment, King Minos of Crete makes Athens send seven boys and seven girls every year. These young people are put into a maze called the labyrinth, where a monster named the Minotaur lives and kills them. But one boy, Theseus, bravely fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a modern version of Theseus — a brave hero facing a deadly challenge.
original: An important inspiration for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of classical Greek mythology. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story the city of Athens is ruled by Crete, but the Athenians rebel. As a punishment, Minos the king of Crete forces the Athenians to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The youths are thrown into the labyrinth and eaten by a monster that lives there called the Minotaur. But one of the youths, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a futuristic Theseus.

simplified: Zoos bring people and animals together. They can teach the public about saving animals and nature, and inspire people to help protect them. Some zoos give a safe home to animals that were treated badly in circuses or pets that were left by their owners. Zoos also do important research on things like how animals behave and how to treat their illnesses.
original: By bringing people and animals together, zoos have the potential to educate the public about conservation issues and inspire people to protect animals and their habitats. Some zoos provide a safe environment for animals which have been mistreated in circuses, or pets which have been abandoned. Zoos also carry out important research into subjects like animal behaviour and how to treat illnesses.

simplified: A new trend is growing against consumerism – the 'buy nothing' trend. It started in Canada in the early 1990s and then spread to the US. There, it became a way to say no to spending too much money and buying too many things, especially on Black Friday and Cyber Monday, which happen during Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day, people hold protests and sometimes cut up their credit cards. During the year, Buy Nothing groups help people give away, share, or fix things they already have instead of buying new ones.
original: A different trend is springing up in opposition to consumerism – the 'buy nothing' trend. The idea originated in Canada in the early 1990s and then moved to the US, where it became a rejection of the overspending and overconsumption of Black Friday and Cyber Monday during Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day people organise various types of protests and cut up their credit cards. Throughout the year, Buy Nothing groups organise the exchange and repair of items they already own.

simplified: Is graffiti art or vandalism? It depends on how you see it. But in many places, writing or painting on public or private property is seen as vandalism. Many street artists have been stopped by police, and some have had to pay money as punishment. City governments often complain that it costs a lot to clean graffiti from buildings, buses, and trains.
original: Is graffiti art or vandalism? This depends on your point of view, but in many countries, writing or painting on public or private property is considered vandalism. Many street artists have been stopped by the police and some have had to pay fines. Many city councils complain about the high cost of cleaning graffiti off buildings, buses and trains.

simplified: What do people in the art world think about graffiti and street art? Lately, more people see it as real art. Big shows of street art have happened in galleries in Paris, London, and Los Angeles. In 2008, the American artist Elura Emerald held a street art show in a New York gallery. She supported street artists, saying, "Artists who paint on the street are just expressing themselves, not hurting anyone. They should be appreciated and celebrated."
original: What does the art world think of graffiti and street art? Recently, there has been a growing recognition of its value as an art form. There have been major exhibitions of street art in galleries in Paris, London and Los Angeles. The American artist Elura Emerald organised a street art exhibition at a New York gallery in 2008. She defended street artists, saying 'artists who paint on the street are merely expressing themselves, not hurting anyone. They should be appreciated and celebrated'.

simplified: Most people have four to six dreams every night after age ten. That’s about 2,000 dreams a year. By age 80, the average person may have had 140,000 dreams. Even though we forget 95 to 99 out of every 100 dreams, we still remember a few thousand in our lives. It’s not hard to believe that sometimes, by chance, something in a dream happens later in real life—especially if it’s something common, like seeing a friend or missing a bus.
original: If most people have four to six dreams every night after the age of ten, that's as many as 2,000 dreams per year. So, by the time they reach 80 years old the average person might have had 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95–99 per cent of our dreams, that's still a few thousand remembered dreams across a lifetime. It's not too difficult to believe that, by coincidence, a dream event is followed by a real-life event that's similar to it, especially if the subject of the dream is something that happens often in everyday life.

simplified: The Hunger Games happens in the future, after North America has been destroyed. The new country is called Panem. It has twelve poor areas, called districts, and a rich central city called the Capitol. The Capitol controls everything and has all the power. Each district makes something different for the Capitol. District 12, where the story starts, mines all the coal for the country. There used to be a thirteenth district, but it fought against the Capitol long ago, and the Capitol destroyed it.
original: The Hunger Games takes place in the future, after the destruction of North America. The country is called Panem and is made up of twelve poor districts governed by the wealthy Capitol. The Capitol holds absolute power over the nation. Each district is responsible for producing different things for the Capitol. District 12, where the story begins, provides all the coal for the country. There used to be a thirteenth district but they rebelled against the Capitol in the past and were destroyed.

simplified: Wild animals often come into cities to find food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started entering homes and gardens at the edge of the city to eat. They open trash bins and take fruit from gardens and fruit trees. Some bold baboons have even gone inside houses and taken food from kitchen cupboards and refrigerators! Baboons can be dangerous and have attacked many pets, so it's not surprising that many people in the city don't like having them around.
original: Often wild animals come into cities to look for food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming into residential areas on the edge of the city to feed. They open rubbish bins and eat fruit from gardens and orchards. Some brave baboons have even come into people's houses and taken food from kitchen cupboards and fridges! Baboons can be aggressive and have attacked a lot of pet animals, so understandably, many city residents don't welcome their presence.

simplified: Many bridge accidents happen while the bridge is being built. These accidents often happen because of a mistake by the engineers, like a wrong calculation. The bridge then falls down under its own weight, which can kill the workers on it at the time.
original: A large number of bridge accidents occur during the construction of the bridge itself. These accidents are often due to an error made by the engineers, such as a miscalculation. The bridge collapses under its own weight, and this can be deadly for the workers on it at the time.

simplified: George Lucas was one of the first movie directors to build his story around the 17 steps of the hero's journey. Usually, the hero begins living a normal life, but then something happens that pulls them into a big adventure that changes their life. At the start of Star Wars, Luke lives a simple life with his aunt and uncle, fixing robots. When he finds Princess Leia’s message inside the robot R2-D2, meant for Obi-Wan Kenobi, it becomes “the call to adventure” — the moment that starts the hero’s journey.
original: George Lucas was one of the early film directors to directly base his story on the 17 stages of the hero's journey. Typically the hero starts the story living an ordinary life, but something happens that calls them to an adventure that changes everything. At the beginning of Star Wars, Luke lives an ordinary life with his aunt and uncle, repairing robots. When he finds Princess Leia's message to Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2D2, it is 'the call to adventure' that starts the hero on his journey.

simplified: Another idea to stop a big space rock (called a PHA) from hitting Earth is to destroy it with a nuclear bomb. It sounds like a movie story — and it was the plot of the 1998 film *Armageddon* — but it’s also part of a real plan from NASA called HAMMER, which stands for Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response. This plan uses eight-ton rockets aimed at the space rock to push it off its path. If the rock is too close to Earth for that to work, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to blow it up instead.
original: Another suggested defence against a PHA on course to hit Earth is to blow it up using a nuclear weapon. It may sound like a plot from a film, and it was the subject of the 1998 film Armageddon, but the Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response (HAMMER) is a genuine NASA proposal. The eight-ton rockets would be fired at an approaching asteroid with the hope of bumping it off course. If the asteroid was too close to Earth for this plan to work, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to blow it up instead.

simplified: According to Campbell, the hero first says no to the adventure, but then a mentor appears and helps them. The hero then decides to enter the "special world" where the adventure begins. There, they face tests, meet friends, and fight enemies while getting ready for their biggest challenge. For Luke, the mentor is Obi-Wan, his friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO, and the enemy is Darth Vader. All of this happens in the special world of the Death Star.
original: According to Campbell, the hero at first refuses the call to adventure, but a mentor appears who helps them and they decide to 'cross the threshold' and travel into the 'special world' where the adventure happens. The next stage consists of passing tests, fighting enemies and meeting friends as the hero prepares to face their biggest challenge. For Luke the mentor is, of course, Obi-Wan, the friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO and the enemy is Darth Vader inside the special world of the Death Star.

simplified: Some things we don’t use much might seem useless, but they can be helpful to someone else. Thanks to the internet, online groups have found a way to make money by sharing these unused things. With websites and social media groups that help people buy and sell used items, it’s now very easy for people to share things directly with each other. This is called the sharing economy.
original: Underutilised items may seem useless to some, but could be an asset to others. With the advent of the internet, online communities have figured out a way to generate profit from the sharing of those underused assets. Using websites and social media groups that facilitate the buying and selling of second-hand goods, it is now easier than ever for peer-to-peer sharing activities to take place. And this is known as the sharing economy.

simplified: In the 18th and 19th centuries, two main ideas about dreams became popular. One idea was that the things we see in dreams show hidden thoughts and feelings we are not aware of. Freud believed that if we understand our dreams, we can understand these hidden feelings and the problems they cause. The other idea was the opposite. It said that dreams are just random brain activity while the brain sorts out memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings by turning them into a story.
original: Around the 18th and 19th centuries two main ideas about dreams became popular. One was the idea that the things we see in our dreams represent things hidden from our conscious mind. Freud believed that if we understand what dreams are telling us, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. However, the other theory was the opposite. It said that dreams are just a collection of random activity in the brain while it's organising memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and put them into some sort of story.

simplified: I work for myself as a freelancer. This is good because I decide what to do and how to use my time. At first, I worked from home, but it was hard to focus. There were too many distractions: housework, making tea, or family members needing help. Then I tried working at a café nearby. But the internet was slow, and I drank too much coffee. In the end, I chose to rent a desk in a shared office with five other freelancers. I like getting ready in the morning and going to work. It helps me concentrate, just like in a regular office.
original: I'm a freelancer and work for myself. This is great because I am in control of what I do and how I spend my time. At first, I was working from home, but I found it really hard to concentrate. There were just too many distractions around: housework that needed doing, another cup of tea, my family members wanting my attention for various things. So I started to go to a nearby café to work, but the Wi-Fi connection wasn't ideal and I found myself drinking too much coffee. In the end, I decided to rent a desk in a co-working space with five other freelancers like myself. I liked getting dressed to go to work in the morning and being able to focus in an office environment.

simplified: Whether NASA can find the rest of the medium-sized near-Earth objects (NEOs) depends on getting money to build a space telescope called NEOCam. It is 0.5 metres wide and would use infrared light to spot asteroids. If NASA gets the money, it could probably finish the job in ten years. After finding them, the planetary defence team would still need to figure out how to protect Earth from the most dangerous asteroids – the ones called Potentially Hazardous Asteroids (PHAs). These are asteroids that could come close to Earth and are big enough to cause serious harm if they hit.
original: Whether NASA can find the remaining middle-sized NEOs depends on getting the money to build NEOCam, a 0.5-metre space telescope which would use infrared light to locate asteroids. If it did get the money, it could probably achieve its goal in ten years. Once logged, the planetary defence team would still need to work out how to defend the planet against being hit by the truly worrying asteroids – the PHAs.

simplified: The 'buy nothing' trend is now popular with social media influencers, who usually suggest clothes and makeup to buy. Some YouTubers now tell their viewers not to buy anything for months or even a whole year. Two friends in Canada tried only buying food for one year. At first, they stopped buying things like clothes, electronics, or household items for three months. Then, they stopped paying for services like haircuts, eating out, or petrol. By the end of the year, they had saved $55,000.
original: The 'buy nothing' trend has now reached influencers on social media who usually share posts of clothing and make-up that they recommend for people to buy. Some YouTube stars now encourage their viewers not to buy anything at all for periods as long as a year. Two friends in Canada spent a year working towards buying only food. For the first three months they learned how to live without buying electrical goods, clothes or things for the house. For the next stage, they gave up services, for example haircuts, eating out at restaurants or buying petrol for their cars. In one year, they'd saved $55,000.

simplified: Religion is very important to Pi. His family is Hindu, but he wants to learn about other religions too. He becomes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. To everyone’s surprise, Pi says he is Hindu, Muslim, and Christian all at the same time. When his family and teachers tell him to pick only one religion, he refuses. He says, "I just want to love God." After that, his family and teachers decide to let him choose what he believes.
original: Religion is important to Pi. Though his family is Hindu, he is curious about other religions and he makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. To everyone's surprise, Pi declares himself to be simultaneously Hindu, Muslim and Christian. When his family and teachers ask him to choose just one religion, Pi refuses, saying 'I just want to love God'. From that moment, his family and teachers decide to let him make his own mind up about religion.

simplified: Some people believe that writing down your dreams can help you have lucid dreams. A lucid dream is when you know you are dreaming and can make choices that change what happens in the dream. For example, you could turn a scary dream into a calm one, or guide the dream like a movie director. This way, instead of just trying to understand your dreams, you are helping to create them. But you might still want to have some regular dreams too, because they let your mind show you what you’re thinking or feeling deep down.
original: Some people think writing your dreams down can open your mind to lucid dreaming. Lucid dreams are dreams where you're not only aware you're dreaming but you can make decisions to affect the events of your dreams. So, maybe you can turn a nightmare into a safe-feeling dream, or you can direct the plot of your dream like a film director. Then, instead of just working out the meaning of your dreams, you'll be creating them, though you might want to continue having some dreams that allow your subconscious to tell you what's on your mind!

simplified: People may not know they are part of the problem with throwaway clothes, even if they give their old clothes to charity. That’s because charity shops cannot sell all the clothes they get. Fast fashion becomes outdated very quickly and is often made from low-quality material, so it’s hard to recycle. Many people don’t want to buy it second-hand. As a result, large amounts of clothing are just thrown away. A lot of the clothes that charities can’t sell are sent to other countries, which creates more problems for the environment and local economies.
original: People might not realise they are part of the disposable clothing problem because they donate their unwanted clothes to charities. But charity shops can't sell all those unwanted clothes. 'Fast fashion' goes out of fashion as quickly as it came in and is often too poor quality to recycle; people don't want to buy it second-hand. Huge quantities end up being thrown away, and a lot of clothes that charities can't sell are sent abroad, causing even more economic and environmental problems.

simplified: Some people don’t stop after one big adventure. They keep looking for new challenges. Meagan McGrath from Canada is one of them. She has climbed the tallest mountain on every continent, biked all the way across Canada, and run a long race in the Sahara Desert where it was 45ºC — very hot! But maybe her most amazing trip was skiing to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a deep crack in the ice, called a glacier, and had to be saved. Many people would have stopped then, but Meagan kept going. Forty days later, she reached the South Pole. She pulled a sled behind her the whole time. On it were her tent and all her food. She did this in freezing weather and through storms with strong winds and ice.
original: Not content with one amazing trip, some of today's adventurers go from challenge to challenge. Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on each continent, ridden a bike across Canada and run a long-distance race in the Sahara Desert in 45ºC heat. But perhaps her most remarkable journey was a skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and had to be rescued. Many of us would have given up at that point, but Meagan decided to carry on. She reached the South Pole forty days later, having pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food behind her through freezing conditions and ice storms.

simplified: Blek le Rat began by painting rats on the walls in Paris, his home city. Today, he wants people to think about social problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities to help residents notice and think about homelessness.
original: Blek le Rat started out painting rats on the walls of his home city, Paris. Nowadays, he tries to make people think about different social issues and problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities to encourage residents to think about the problem of homelessness.

simplified: In some places, local governments have tried to stop random graffiti by giving artists special areas where they can paint. For example, in Taiwan, there are "graffiti zones" where people can freely paint and write on walls. In São Paulo, Brazil, the city even lets some graffiti artists paint on subway trains.
original: In some areas, councils have tried to encourage artists not to paint graffiti randomly on walls by allowing them to work in designated areas. Taiwan is one such place and there are 'graffiti zones' where artists are free to paint and write on walls. In São Paulo in Brazil, the city council has even allowed some graffiti artists to paint on the city's subway trains.

simplified: Faith47 is from Cape Town, South Africa. She makes large, colourful paintings of people and animals and enjoys working in different places. You can find her art on sidewalks, in empty factories, and on old, unused cars. She likes that most street art does not last long — rain, wind, or city cleaners often remove it. To her, this shows how life is always changing, with things ending and new things beginning.
original: Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals and likes to explore different locations. Her work is found on pavements, in empty factories and on abandoned cars. She likes the fact that most street art is temporary and will soon be removed by weather or cleaners from the city council. For her, this reflects how life is full of change with its cycle of endings and new beginnings.

simplified: In her old job, Gabriela was used to a work culture where people respected authority and everyone knew their role. In this kind of culture, bosses make the important decisions and people rarely disagree with them. But her Swedish team was used to a different style. They worked in a culture where employees and managers often work together to solve problems and make choices. In this setting, leaders act more like coaches or helpers. They support independent thinking and expect team members to share their opinions, even if they disagree.
original: In her previous work environment, Gabriela was used to a high power distance culture where power and authority are respected and everyone has their rightful place. In such a culture, leaders make the big decisions and are not often challenged. Her Swedish team, however, were used to working in a low power distance culture where subordinates often work together with their bosses to find solutions and make decisions. Here, leaders act as coaches or mentors who encourage independent thought and expect to be challenged.

simplified: When Gabriela noticed the cultural differences between her and her team, she decided to talk openly with them about how they felt about her way of leading. Her team was happy she asked and said honestly that they were not used to being told exactly what to do. They liked having space to take action on their own and be creative. When Gabriela told them exactly what she wanted, they felt she didn’t trust them to do their work well. They also realised that Gabriela felt hurt when they questioned or changed her decisions. They explained that this was just how they had always worked — not to upset her, but as part of their normal way of working.
original: When Gabriela became aware of the cultural differences between her and her team, she took the initiative to have an open conversation with them about their feelings about her leadership. Pleased to be asked for their thoughts, Gabriela's team openly expressed that they were not used to being told what to do. They enjoyed having more room for initiative and creative freedom. When she told her team exactly what she needed them to do, they felt that she didn't trust them to do their job well. They realised that Gabriela was taking it personally when they tried to challenge or make changes to her decisions, and were able to explain that it was how they'd always worked.

simplified: Os Gêmeos are twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint small tags and large, colorful pictures of people on buildings. Their art is often so big that they need cranes to help them. In 2007, they painted an entire castle in Scotland.
original: Os Gêmeos are identical twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint everything from tags to huge, colourful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their work is often so big that they need cranes to help them work. In 2007, they covered the whole of a castle in Scotland with paint.

simplified: People have always painted and written on walls. A long time ago, people in Africa and Europe painted animals and people on cave walls. Long after that, people in ancient Greece, Italy, Syria, and Iraq wrote or drew on buildings — this is called graffiti. In the old Roman town of Pompeii, scientists have found many graffiti messages written in Latin. They talk about religion, politics, love, and even some magic!
original: People have been painting and writing on walls throughout history. In prehistoric times, people in Africa and Europe used to paint pictures of animals and people in caves. Graffiti has been found on buildings at ancient sites in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In the Roman town of Pompeii, archaeologists have found numerous examples of graffiti written in Latin. These include religious, political and romantic messages, and even some magic spells!

simplified: Have you ever wanted to climb Mount Everest or walk to the South Pole? If yes, you're not the only one. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the tallest mountains or walk across big parts of the world. Long ago, explorers used maps and compasses, but today’s adventurers use modern tools like GPS and satellite phones. Many of these travelers love nature and use their trips to help people understand environmental problems better. Others want to help those in need and raise money for good causes.
original: Have you ever dreamt of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? If so, you're not alone. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the world's highest mountains or walk across continents. Unlike the explorers of the past who used maps and compasses, today's adventurers travel with modern technology like GPS and satellite phones. Many adventurers are nature lovers who use their travels to help raise awareness about a range of environmental issues, while others are keen to help people in need and raise money for charities.

simplified: The first is DART – the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Scientists plan to test DART on a small moon that goes around an asteroid called Didymos. This moon, nicknamed 'Didymoon', is 150 metres wide and circles its larger 800-metre-wide asteroid. When DART hits it, the crash should change the moon's path just enough so that telescopes on Earth can see the difference.
original: The first is DART – the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Plans are scheduled to test DART on the moon of an asteroid called Didymos. 'Didymoon' is 150 metres wide, orbiting its 800-metre mother, and hopefully the impact of DART will knock it out of its orbit enough for Earth-based telescopes to pick up.

simplified: The main character is a 16-year-old girl named Katniss Everdeen. Her father died in a mine accident, so she has to find food for her family. She hunts in the woods near District 12 with her friend Gale and becomes very good at using a bow and arrow. When her younger sister, Prim, is picked to be a tribute, Katniss says she will go in her place. The other tribute from District 12 is a boy named Peeta, and Katniss ends up in a difficult relationship with him.
original: The heroine of the story, a sixteen year old girl called Katniss Everdeen, has lost her father in a mining accident and has to provide food for her family. She hunts in the woods around District 12 with her friend Gale and becomes very skilful with a bow and arrow. When her younger sister, Prim, is chosen as one of the tributes, Katniss volunteers to go instead. The other tribute from District 12 is a boy named Peeta and Katniss soon finds herself in a complicated relationship with him.

simplified: Writing about your dreams helps you remember more of what happened in them. Think about who was in the dream and where it took place — these details can help you understand the dream better. After a week, you might be surprised by how much you’ve written. Now you can start to see how your dreams connect to what’s happening in your life and how you’re feeling each day.
original: Writing about your dreams will mean you start to remember more details about the dream, so think about the people and place where the dream happened as they might add to the meaning too. Over the period of a week you'll be surprised how much you've written down. Now you can start connecting your dreams to the events and feelings in your daily life.

simplified: Long ago, many bridges were built from wood and could catch fire more easily. This was especially true for old train bridges. The sparks made by metal train wheels rolling on metal tracks could sometimes set the bridge on fire, burning it down completely.
original: Historically, more bridges were made of wood and were much more susceptible to fire. This was particularly true of old-fashioned train bridges, where the spark created by the steel wheels and steel tracks could sometimes cause a bridge to catch fire and burn to the ground.

simplified: It's hard to say how street art will change in the future, but some patterns are starting to appear. Most street artists are young and paint in their own city or local area. But more and more, artists are travelling to other countries to create art. Others are using the internet to talk with each other and share pictures of their work online. Also, the art world is starting to see street art as real art. Even though we don't know exactly what will happen, one thing is clear: street art isn't going away.
original: It is impossible to know how street art will develop in the future but certain trends are emerging. While most street artists are young people who paint in their city or neighbourhood, more and more street artists are travelling and working around the globe. Other artists are using the internet to talk to each other and share photos of their work. Also, the art world is giving more recognition to street art as a legitimate art form. Although we don't know what will happen to street art in the future, we can be sure that it is here to stay!

simplified: Suzanne Collines always felt upset when she saw news about wars. When she was a child, her father was a pilot in the US Air Force and fought in Vietnam. Her mother tried to protect her by not telling her what was happening in the war. But Suzanne still saw news reports about it and knew her dad was there. This made her very afraid.
original: Suzanne Collines has always found news programmes of wars upsetting. When she was a child, her father was a pilot in the US Air Force and he fought in Vietnam. Her mother tried to protect her by not telling her what was happening in the war, but she still saw news programmes about the war and knew that her dad was there. It was a very frightening experience for her.

simplified: A global survey by PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) collected answers from over 40,000 young adults (born between 1983 and 1993) and older workers. They shared their thoughts on workplace culture, how people talk and work together, pay, career growth, and balancing work with personal life. In another global survey, Deloitte asked over 10,000 young adults about their views on the challenges and chances they see in today’s work world.
original: In a global survey conducted by PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC), more than 40,000 millennial (born between 1983 and 1993) and non-millennial responses were collected on the topics of workplace culture, communication and working styles, pay structure, career development, work–life balance, etc. In a separate global survey conducted by Deloitte, more than 10,000 millennials participated in a study about their perceptions of the threats and opportunities in the complex world of work.

simplified: Erik Weihenmayer from the United States is an adventurer. He has biked through the deserts of Morocco, kayaked in the Grand Canyon, and climbed Mount Everest. What's amazing is that Erik has been blind since he was 13. Besides his adventures, he encourages people with disabilities to stay active. He also leads groups of young blind people on climbing trips.
original: Erik Weihenmayer from the United States is a multi-adventurer. He's ridden a bike through the deserts of Morocco, kayaked through the Grand Canyon and climbed Everest. Amazingly, Erik has been blind since the age of 13. Apart from his travels, he tries to encourage people with disabilities to live active lives and takes groups of young blind people on climbing expeditions.

simplified: Online platforms make it easy for people to earn a little extra money. For example, busy parents might not have had time to set up a stand at a local market or garage sale to sell their kids’ old things. But now, with online marketplaces, they can sell barely used baby clothes, prams, and other baby gear their children have outgrown. This helps them get some of their money back.
original: Democratised online platforms are providing a chance for people to make a quick buck or two. To give an example, busy parents previously might not have bothered with setting up a stall at the local market or car boot sale to sell their children's old equipment, but with online marketplaces, parents are now able to sell on those hardly worn baby clothes that their children have outgrown and the expensive pushchairs and baby equipment they have invested in, so as to put some cash back into their pockets.

simplified: Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days together in a lifeboat. They face hunger, sickness, and tiredness. They survive strong storms and the hot Pacific sun. Sometimes, Pi feels comfort in his three religions, but other times he feels very lonely and sad. Then, one day, they see the Mexican coast ahead — and everything changes. I won’t tell you the ending, so you’ll have to read the book to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker when they reach land.
original: Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days in the lifeboat. They live through hunger, illness and exhaustion. They endure violent storms and the burning heat of the Pacific sun, but somehow they survive. At times, Pi finds comfort in his three religions, but at other times he is overcome with loneliness and despair. Finally, the Mexican coast appears on the horizon and everything changes. It would be a shame to give away the ending, so you will have to read the book yourself to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker once land is in sight.

simplified: Chloe came home from school, made a cup of coffee, and took it to her bedroom. She had homework to do, but she could do it later. She wanted to enjoy the quiet time before her parents got home and the house got busy with talking, TV, or her dad playing his favorite jazz music while he cooked dinner. She liked this part of the day because she could play with her pet rats.
original: Chloe arrived home from school, made herself a cup of coffee and took it up to her bedroom. She had some homework to do, but that could wait for later. She wanted to enjoy the quiet hour before her parents arrived home and the house filled up with the evening sounds of chatter, television or her dad listening to his beloved jazz while he cooked dinner. She liked this time of day too because she could play with her pet rats.

simplified: In 2010, NASA's planetary defence team had found and recorded 90% of the large asteroids near Earth, about 1km wide. These are called 'near-Earth objects' or NEOs, and are as big as mountains. They travel within 50 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. NASA says there are about 50 left to find, but none of the 887 already known are a serious threat to Earth.
original: In 2010, the planetary defence team at NASA had identified and logged 90 per cent of the asteroids near Earth measuring 1km wide. These 'near-Earth objects', or NEOs, are the size of mountains and include anything within 50 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. With an estimated 50 left to log, NASA says none of the 887 it knows about are a significant danger to the planet.

simplified: Auggie decides to go to school and faces his first day. Like any child starting at a new school, he feels very nervous. But because of his appearance, it’s especially hard. No one wants to sit next to him, and he sees other kids staring or whispering about him. Luckily, he becomes friends with Jack, a boy in his class, and Summer, a girl he talks to at lunch. But the problems don’t stop. Auggie learns that some classmates are afraid to touch him, thinking he might make them sick. As the school year goes on, Auggie has many difficult moments and a few good ones, until a surprising and upsetting event at a school camp changes everything.
original: Having decided to go to school, Auggie then has to face his first day. Like every child starting at a new school, he is really anxious. But because of the way he looks, it's an agonising experience. Nobody wants to sit next to him and he notices other kids staring at him or talking about him behind their hands. Fortunately, he makes friends with Jack, a boy in his class, and Summer, a girl he chats with at lunch. But it's not just the first day that's hard. Auggie soon learns that his classmates don't want to touch him for fear of catching 'the plague'. As he goes through the school year, Auggie goes through many intense ups and downs till finally an unexpected and traumatic event at a school camp changes things completely.

simplified: The two men looked toward the north end of the land. It went on as far as they could see. The fences were so far away, they were hard to spot. No matter how bored or angry a teenage boy got, he couldn’t walk away and escape. Sam looked at the largest horse, pawing the ground with its heavy hooves. Could the boy ride? he wondered. A good rider could get into a lot of trouble out here, so far from anyone. But maybe someone who didn’t know anything about horses—and just wanted to get away from his dad—could get into even more trouble.
original: The two men looked towards the northern end of the property. It stretched as far as the eye could see. Even the fences were barely visible from where they stood. However bored and rebellious a teenage boy might get, it wasn't possible to escape on foot. Sam looked at the biggest of the horses, kicking at the ground with its heavy hooves. Could the boy ride? he wondered. There was a whole load of trouble a good rider could get into out here, miles away from anyone. But maybe there was even more trouble for someone who knew nothing about horses and wanted to get away from his father.

simplified: More than 4,000 people, from age thirteen to eighty, have reached the top of Mount Everest. Even though climbing tall mountains in very cold weather and strong storms is still very dangerous, the best climbers today want new challenges. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner from Austria started loving mountain climbing when she was a teenager. After school, she worked as a nurse but kept climbing in her free time.
original: Over 4,000 climbers, aged from thirteen to eighty have been to the top of Everest. Though climbing high mountains in freezing conditions and violent storms is still extremely dangerous, the world's best climbers now look for new challenges. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner from Austria fell in love with mountain climbing as a teenager. When she left school, she worked as a nurse, but kept climbing in her free time.

simplified: After climbing Everest, Gerlinde decided to climb all fourteen of the world’s highest mountains. These mountains are over 8,000 metres tall. To make it harder, she climbs without oxygen tanks. This is dangerous because there is very little oxygen at the top of high mountains, which can harm the brain and body. Gerlinde uses her fame as a climber to help a charity that supports poor children and orphans in Nepal.
original: Having climbed Everest, Gerlinde decided to climb all fourteen of the world's 8,000 metre peaks. To increase the challenge, Gerlinde climbs without using oxygen tanks. This is risky as low oxygen levels at the top of high mountains can affect brain and body functioning. Gerlinde uses her fame as a climber to support a charity for poor children and orphans in Nepal.

simplified: If we look around at the things we have bought over the years, we will probably see that not everything we own is useful. For example, the thick wool coat we bought because it looked cool, even though we live in a hot, tropical place. Or the old smartphone we stopped using when we got a newer one. Maybe the car we only drive on weekends. Or even the guest room in our home that we now use to store things instead of letting guests sleep there.
original: If we look around us at the things we have purchased at some point in our lives, we would no doubt notice that not everything we own is being put to good use: the thick woollen coat which we thought looked trendy despite the fact that we live in a tropical country, the smartphone that got put away when we bought ourselves the newest model, the car that only gets used at the weekends, or even the guest room in our house that somehow got turned into a storeroom.

simplified: For a long time, and in many parts of the world, people have believed that dreams can predict the future. They thought dreams were messages from the gods, meant to give them knowledge or understanding. Even now, many people remember a time when they dreamed about something — like an event, a place, or a person — and later, that dream actually happened in real life.
original: Throughout history and across cultures, dreams have been associated with prophecy. People thought dreams were messages from the gods, sent to give us knowledge or insight. Even today, many people can recall a time they dreamed about an event, place or person and then, later, the dream came true in real life.

simplified: Some of the largest and most costly transport projects in the world have been about building bridges. Bridges are important because they let cars, trucks, and trains cross over water, deep valleys, or other roads. Because they play such a big role in how we travel, bridges are a key part of civil engineering. Engineers study them very carefully, especially if a bridge ever falls down.
original: Some of the biggest and most expensive transportation projects in the world have involved building bridges. Bridges are crucial links that carry cars, trucks and trains across bodies of water, mountain gorges or other roads. As a result, they are one of the most important aspects of civil engineering and are subject to intense scrutiny, especially when they collapse.

simplified: After weeks of frustration, Gabriela emailed her Swedish manager about problems with her team. He only asked if the team was still performing well and what she thought could improve teamwork. Gabriela found his response unclear and felt he wasn’t handling the situation well.
original: After weeks of frustration, Gabriela emailed her Swedish manager about the issues she was facing with her team. Her manager simply asked her if she felt her team was still performing, and what she thought would help her better collaborate with her team members. Gabriela found her manager vague and didn't feel as if he was managing the situation satisfactorily.

simplified: Dogs that live in groups have learned that people are more likely to give food to small, cute dogs. So, the smaller dogs go and beg for food for the whole group. Some dogs have even learned to use the city’s subway to move around their area. Scientists don’t know exactly how the dogs know when to get off the train. One idea is that dogs use their strong sense of smell and can recognize the smells of places they like. Another idea is that they learn the names of subway stations from the announcements. Either way, people on the subway are now so used to seeing dogs that they hardly notice them anymore.
original: Dogs that live in packs have learnt that humans are more likely to give food to smaller, cuter dogs so those dogs are sent to beg for food for the whole pack. Some dogs have even learnt to use the city's metro system to get from one part of their territory to another! Scientists are not sure how the dogs know when to get off the train. One idea is that they use their excellent sense of smell and have learnt to recognise the scents of their favourite destinations. Another possibility is that they have learnt to recognise the names of stations they hear in announcements. Either way, metro passengers have now got so used to the sight of dogs on the trains that they travel largely unnoticed by locals.

simplified: Ed Stafford from the UK is the first person to walk the whole length of the Amazon River. He began at a small stream in the Andes mountains in Peru. Two years and four months later, he reached the river's end in Brazil. He walked 6,000 kilometres. The Amazon rainforest has dangerous animals like poisonous snakes, crocodiles, and jaguars, so Ed was always in danger. Luckily, he stayed safe and only got a few thousand mosquito and ant bites.
original: Ed Stafford from the UK is the first person to walk the length of the Amazon River. He started by a small stream in the Andes mountains of Peru and arrived at the river's mouth in Brazil, two years and four months later, having walked 6,000 kilometres. The Amazon rainforest is home to poisonous snakes, crocodiles and jaguars, so Ed was in constant danger. Luckily, he survived with nothing worse than a few thousand mosquito and ant bites.

simplified:
In Britain, the average person spends over £1,000 a year on new clothes. That’s about four per cent of their income. It might not seem like a lot, but this number hides two serious problems—one for society and one for the environment.  

First, many people use credit cards to pay for clothes. Right now, each adult in Britain owes about £670 to credit card companies. That’s 66 per cent of what they spend on clothes each year. So, people are spending money they don’t yet have.  

Second, they’re using that borrowed money to buy clothes they often don’t need. Every year, Britain throws away 300,000 tons of clothing. Most of it ends up buried in landfill sites, where it harms the environment.
original: In Britain, the average person spends more than £1,000 on new clothes a year, which is around four per cent of their income. That might not sound like much, but that figure hides two far more worrying trends for society and for the environment. First, a lot of that consumer spending is via credit cards. British people currently owe approximately £670 per adult to credit card companies. That's 66 per cent of the average wardrobe budget. Also, not only are people spending money they don't have, they're using it to buy things they don't need. Britain throws away 300,000 tons of clothing a year, most of which goes into landfill sites.

simplified: Ed could not have made his journey without technology. He used a radio to talk to people in the rainforest, asking for food and for permission to cross their land. Many came to meet him and helped him through the hardest parts of the journey. As he walked, Ed wrote a blog, sharing his daily experiences. He used the media attention from his trip to speak out against the destruction of the rainforest and to raise money for environmental groups and children's charities in Brazil and Peru.
original: Ed's walk would have been impossible without technology. He used a radio to ask the people of the rainforest for food and permission to cross their land. Many of them came to meet him and helped guide him through the most difficult terrain. As he walked Ed wrote a blog, recording his day-to-day experiences. He used the media interest in his trip to protest about the destruction of the rainforest and raise money for environmental and children's charities in Brazil and Peru.

simplified: Businesses have realized that the sharing economy can make money by using resources that are not being used enough. A popular business idea now is for companies to create websites or apps that connect customers with people who offer a product or service. For example, Airbnb helps people rent out their empty rooms or homes to travelers who need a place to stay. This can earn the homeowners extra money. Another example is Uber, which lets people use their own cars to give rides to others and earn money in their spare time.
original: Businesses have caught on to the profitability of the sharing economy and are seeking to gain from making use of those underutilised resources. A business model that has rapidly risen in popularity sees companies providing an online platform that puts customers in contact with those who can provide a particular product or service. Companies like Airbnb act as a middleman for people to cash in on their unused rooms and houses and let them out as lucrative accommodation. Another example is Uber, which encourages people to use their own personal cars as taxis to make some extra cash in their free time.

simplified: One of the main jobs of modern zoos is helping with international breeding programmes, especially for endangered animals. In the wild, rare animals often struggle to find mates and face threats from poachers, habitat loss, and predators. Good zoos give these animals a safe place to live and breed. Also, when wild populations get smaller, they can become too similar genetically. Breeding programmes help prevent this — zoo-bred animals can be released into the wild to increase genetic variety.
original: One of the most important modern functions of zoos is supporting international breeding programmes, particularly for endangered species. In the wild, some of the rarest species have difficulty in finding mates and breeding, and they might also be threatened by poachers, loss of their habitat and predators. A good zoo will enable these species to live and breed in a secure environment. In addition, as numbers of some wild species drop, there is an increased danger of populations becoming too genetically similar. Breeding programmes provide a safeguard: zoo-bred animals can be released into the wild to increase genetic diversity.

simplified: These types of accidents are very rare, but both boats and trains can cause a bridge to collapse in different ways. Trains can bring down a bridge because they hit it at high speed. Boats, even when moving slowly, can cause collapse because they are very heavy. The best way to prevent bridge failures is to plan for them. New technology that finds weak spots, safer work practices, and improved designs can all help reduce these serious accidents.
original: Both of these kinds of accidents are extremely rare, but boats and trains can cause a bridge to collapse for different reasons. With trains, it's the velocity of the impact that can bring a bridge down. With boats, it's the very large mass they have that can bring about the collapse, even if they are moving very slowly when it occurs. The best way to avoid bridge failures is to plan for them. Modern technologies that can detect structural weakness, safer working environments and better designs can all help to reduce these terrible accidents.

simplified: At first, Pi is very scared of the animals and jumps into the sea. Then he remembers there are hungry sharks in the water near him. He understands he must climb back into the lifeboat. One after another, the animals in the lifeboat kill and eat each other, until only Pi and the tiger are left. Luckily for Pi, the tiger—which he calls Richard Parker—is sick from the sea and does not want to eat him right now.
original: At first, Pi is terrified of the animals and jumps into the ocean. Then he remembers that there are hungry sharks in the water around him and realises his only option is to climb back into the lifeboat. One by one, the animals in the lifeboat kill and eat each other, till only Pi and the tiger are left. Fortunately for Pi, the tiger, who he names Richard Parker, is seasick and has no immediate interest in eating him.

simplified: When Pi is 16, a new government comes into power that his parents do not like. Worried about what might happen, Pi's parents decide to close their zoo and move to Canada. They sell some of the animals to zoos in North America. The family, along with the remaining animals, travel by ship to Canada. During the journey, a terrible storm hits and the ship sinks. Sadly, Pi's family and all the sailors on the ship die in the water. Pi survives and finds himself in a small lifeboat with a hyena, a zebra, an orang-utan, and a very large tiger.
original: When Pi is 16, a new government is elected that his parents don't support. Worried about the future, Pi's parents decide to close the zoo and emigrate to Canada. Some of the animals are sold to zoos in North America and the family travel by ship to Canada taking the animals with them. On the way, there is a terrible storm and the ship sinks. Tragically, Pi's family and the ship's sailors all drown, but Pi finds himself in a lifeboat with a hyena, zebra, orang-utan and an enormous tiger.

simplified: The Hunger Games is a very popular book for teenagers and young adults by American author Suzanne Collins. Since it came out in 2008, it has been translated into 26 languages and sold millions of copies worldwide. It was also the first young readers' book to sell over a million e-copies. Now it is a big Hollywood movie, just as successful. It earned 152.5 million dollars in its first weekend in North America!
original: The Hunger Games is a hugely successful book for teenagers and young adults by the American author Suzanne Collins. Since it was published in 2008 it has been translated into 26 different languages and has sold millions of copies around the world. It is also the first book for young readers to sell more than a million electronic copies. The Hunger Games is now a major Hollywood film and is just as successful. It made 152.5 million dollars in its opening weekend in North America alone!

simplified: Maybe dreams happen when our mind sorts the thoughts we had during the day. But in dreams, these thoughts come as symbols. When we are awake, we think in words, like talking to ourselves in our heads. But when we sleep, the part of the brain that handles language works less, and the part that handles feelings works more. That’s why dreams feel so emotional and strange.
original: Maybe dreams are the result of our mind organising the thoughts we have during the day, but they appear in dreams with symbolic meaning. When we're awake, our thoughts mostly appear in our minds as words, like conversations we have with ourselves. But when we're asleep, the part of our brain that controls language becomes less active while the part that controls emotions becomes more active.

simplified: Good relationships are very important for happiness. One study found that most happy people have strong connections with family and friends, and they spend time with them regularly. It’s also important to have at least one person you can talk to about your feelings—this is called 'self-disclosure'. Just one close friend for deep talks is enough, along with other supportive relationships. Having many friends to do things with or chat about music or football isn’t enough. A deeper connection matters most. Some people need to learn how to listen well to build stronger relationships.
original: Having good relationships is a big part of being happy. In one study, most happy people were found to have strong ties to friends and family and they made sure they spent time with them regularly. You also need at least one person who you discuss personal feelings with – called 'self-disclosure'. Just one person for a heart-to-heart is enough, together with a network of other relationships. It's not enough to have lots of friends just to do things with or chat to about music or football. That deeper connection is all-important. Some people need to learn how to listen effectively to others in order to develop stronger relationships.

simplified: Psychologist Carol Dweck, who supports the idea of a "growth mindset," says the brain can change and grow. This means we can learn new skills, even if we’re not good at them at first. Many people praise results or natural talent, like saying, “You’re so good at noticing small things” or “You’re a natural at planning events.” But studies show it’s better to praise how someone works—like their effort, trying new ways, or solving problems. This kind of praise helps people keep improving and developing their skills.
original: Psychologist and 'growth mindset' proponent Carol Dweck spoke of the plasticity of the brain and our ability to develop skills and talents that we might not have been good at to start with. Many of us tend to focus our praise on the end result and seemingly innate talents, e.g. 'You really have an eye for details' or 'You have a real talent for organising events'. However, research suggests that by focusing on the process of how things are done – praising effort, experimentation and problem-solving strategies – we can encourage the development of new skills and the continued honing of talents.

simplified: The rover checks the air around it from time to time. In 2014, it found a simple organic molecule in the air called methane. Methane is also a main part of natural gas. One thing about methane is that it does not last very long — only a few hundred years. This means something on Mars must be making more of it. NASA says that Mars releases thousands of tons of methane at once. The amount of methane goes up and down with the seasons, almost as if the planet is breathing.
original: The rover analyses the air around it periodically, and in 2014 it found the air contained another of the most basic organic molecules and a key ingredient of natural gas: methane. One of the characteristics of methane is that it only survives a few hundred years. This means that something, somewhere on Mars, is replenishing the supply. According to NASA, Mars emits thousands of tons of methane at a time. The level of methane rises and falls at seasonal intervals in the year, almost as if the planet is breathing it.

simplified: Early in her career, psychologist Carol Dweck from Stanford University gave ten-year-olds problems that were a little too hard. One group liked the challenge and believed they could improve. She called this a 'growth mindset'—they focused on future success. The other group felt judged and thought they had failed. They had a 'fixed mindset' and couldn’t see a way to get better. Some said they might cheat later; others looked for someone who did worse to feel better about themselves.
original: Early in her career, the psychologist Carol Dweck of Stanford University gave a group of ten-year-olds problems that were slightly too hard for them. One group reacted positively, said they loved challenge and understood that their abilities could be developed. She says they had a 'growth mindset' and are focused on what they can achieve in the future. But another group of children felt that their intelligence was being judged and they had failed. They had a 'fixed mindset' and were unable to imagine improving. Some of these children said they might cheat in the future; others looked for someone who had done worse than them to boost their self-esteem.

simplified: Horror films often use empty places. This could be an old hospital, a dark empty house, or a town with no people. There’s something strange about quiet, lonely places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they go away? Maybe the silence itself is scary. Also, it’s easier for film makers because in these places, your phone usually doesn’t work — which makes the story feel more real.
original: Horror films love uninhabited places. This could be an abandoned hospital, a scary empty house or a ghost town. There's something about lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it's also that they are so quiet, which can be very scary too. Of course, abandoned places are also handy for horror film directors in that it's more believable that you will have no phone coverage there either.

simplified: No matter what kind of house it is, the basement is always a scary place in horror movies. It’s usually where something is hiding, or where the bad person keeps their scary tools. Basements are dark and often wet. You can only get there by going down a narrow set of stairs. And they feel creepy, even when there’s nothing actually there.
original: No matter what kind of house it is, the basement is a scary place in horror films. That's usually where something is hiding or where the evil psychopath has hidden their tools. Basements are always dark and often damp. You can only reach them by a narrow staircase. And basements are always creepy, even when there isn't anything down there.

simplified: Gary Collins was a policeman not working at the time. He was on holiday and watching the London riots on TV. He quickly recognised some of the people and decided to end his holiday early to help. He spent six months looking at CCTV videos and identified 190 people. He could even recognise many just by their eyes. His help was very important for the investigation. Even though there were 200,000 hours of video, the facial recognition software only found one person.
original: Gary Collins, an off-duty policeman, was watching the London riots on TV. He immediately recognised several people and cut his holiday short to help with identification. He ended up spending six months going through the CCTV film and managed to identify 190 people, many from their eyes alone. His help was of decisive importance in the investigation. Even with 200,000 hours of footage, facial recognition software managed to identify just one person.

simplified: I find it really interesting to think about how we can make humans evolve faster by upgrading our bodies. Just imagine putting a computer inside your brain! Soon, we might actually be able to do that. It could help us get better at math, improve how we see and hear things, and make our memory stronger. This idea will probably become more normal in the future.
original: Personally, I think it's fascinating to consider how we'll speed up our evolution as a species by augmenting our bodies. Imagine if you could implant a computer inside our brain! Soon we'll be able to do just that and enhance our mathematical ability, audiovisual perception and our memory, and this idea is only going to become more and more commonplace.

simplified: It was an interesting talk, and the speaker was right about a few important things. Take parents’ influence, for example. How can we expect teenagers not to text while doing homework when they see their parents using social media while cooking or waiting at traffic lights? She also made a good point about people wanting to be in more than one place at once. So they keep switching between real-life and online conversations. I see this all the time with my teenage daughter and her friends. They meet up, but then sit together in silence, each one chatting with someone else online.
original: It was a fascinating talk and the speaker really hit the nail on the head with a couple of things. Take parental influence, for instance. How can we expect teenagers not to text while doing their homework when they witness their parents posting on social media while cooking the evening meal or waiting at a red light? She also made a valid point about people wanting to be in two or several places at once. So they switch back and forth between their real-life and online conversations. I see it all the time with my teenage daughter and her friends. They arrange to meet and then sit together in silence while each one engages in a different conversation online.

simplified: Some news makes us think the world is becoming more violent. But there is also good news. From the end of World War II until 1990, there were 30 wars that killed over 100,000 people each. Today, there are still wars inside countries, but countries are living together in peace more often than before. However, terrorist attacks have become much more common in recent years. Also, since World War II, wars have killed many more ordinary people than soldiers. Even so, the numbers for ordinary people are not all bad. Violent crime is nine times more likely to cause death than wars between countries. But the number of murders around the world went down a little. In 2000, 8 people out of every 100,000 were murdered. By 2015, this number was about 5.3 people out of every 100,000.
original: As for news stories that make us think the world is an increasingly violent place, there is cause for some optimism too. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed more than 100,000 people. Today there are still civil wars, but countries are mostly co-existing more peacefully than in the past. However, terrorism has shot up in the last few years and, since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. Even for civilians, though, the statistics are not all bad. Although deaths are nine times more likely to be a result of violent crime than political conflict, the global murder rate fell slightly, from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.

simplified:
Wasfia has spent her life helping to protect human rights. She has seen many international aid projects in her home country, Bangladesh, that teach and train women and girls. But too often, when these projects end, the women are left with no support. Wasfia realized Bangladesh needed to make its own change. So she combined two things she loves: climbing mountains and fighting for human rights. She wanted to change how people in her country see women.

She first started climbing while working on aid work in Tibet and Nepal. In Bangladesh, a flat country near the sea, most people have never even seen a mountain. Now, her efforts are working. People in Bangladesh—and around the world—are starting to pay attention.
original: Wasfia has dedicated her life to supporting human rights and has witnessed numerous international humanitarian projects in her homeland to educate and train women and girls, but once too often they have been left with nothing when such projects have stopped running. Wasfia saw that Bangladesh needed to stand up for itself and so she brought together two of her passions, mountaineering and human rights, in order to try and change attitudes towards women in her country. She originally took up climbing while working on humanitarian campaigns in Tibet and Nepal, as in a coastal, primarily flat country like Bangladesh most people have never set eyes on a mountain. Her campaign seems to be doing the trick as fellow countrymen and women are sitting up and taking notice along with the rest of the world.

simplified: Most people think poor countries are in bad shape: full of extreme poverty, ruled by dictators, and with no real chance to improve. But surprisingly, that’s not true. In fact, big changes are happening. Over the last 20 years, more than 700 million people have earned more money and moved out of poverty. Also, six million fewer children die each year from illness, many more girls now go to school, and millions of people can drink clean water.
original: The majority of people believe that developing countries are in a terrible situation: suffering from incredible poverty, governed by dictators and with little hope for any meaningful change.
